data.title: Executing a task: Cannot find module 'semver'
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I created following scripts in my `package.json`: 

```json
"scripts": {
    "build": "tsc",
    "build:watch": "tsc --watch"
},
```
2. my `tasks.json` looks like this:

```json
{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "type": "npm",
      "script": "build:watch",
      "problemMatcher": ["$tsc-watch"]
    }
  ]
}
```
3. when I execute this tasks I get following error

```sh
> Executing task: npm run build <

module.js:487
    throw err;
    ^

Error: Cannot find module 'semver'
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:485:15)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:437:25)
    at Module.require (module.js:513:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:11:18)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/utils/unsupported.js:2:14)
    at Module._compile (module.js:569:30)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:580:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:503:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:466:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:458:3)
The terminal process terminated with exit code: 1
```

4. I also can't execute the `build` script

5. my `package.json` is really simple at the moment

```json
{
  "name": "foo",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "main": "index.js",
  "license": "MIT",
  "scripts": {
    "build": "tsc",
    "build:watch": "tsc --watch"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@types/node": "^8.0.20",
    "typescript": "^2.4.2"
  },
  "dependencies": {}
}
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

- VSCode Version:  1.15.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Settings:

```
{
    "terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell": []
}
```

Extensions: none

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new terminal
2. Load bash
3. Press any function key F1-F12

A tilde is inserted rather than passing the function key to the terminal.  

Edit: I found a previous workaround based on a similar issue, suggesting to use wsltty, but it doesn't work perfectly either.  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10163

data.title: Emmet: compact boolean attributes won't work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.0 (8b95971d8cccd3afd86b35d4a0e098c189294ff2, 2017-08-09T20:16:18.034Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- vscode-caniuse|aka|0.5.3 vscode-color|ans|0.4.5 vscode-simpler-icons|dav|1.3.0 githistory|don|0.2.3 pgsql|dou|0.0.8 vscode-babel-coloring|dza|0.0.4 vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.14 prettier-vscode|esb|0.22.1 auto-close-tag|for|0.4.3 auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14 RelativePath|jak|1.0.0 sublime-babel-vscode|jos|0.2.6 sublime-keybindings|ms-|2.9.1 material-icon-theme|PKi|2.1.0 vscode-css-peek|pra|1.3.1 seti-icons|qin|0.1.3 quokka-vscode|Wal|1.0.48 (3 theme extensions excluded) --- Emmet has a `profile.allowCompactBoolean` preference [shown here](https://docs.emmet.io/customization/preferences/) that defaults to `true`. For some reason it's not documented in the [syntax profile options](https://docs.emmet.io/customization/syntax-profiles/#create-your-own-profile), but in the code the functionality [seems to also rely on a `compact_bool` flag being set on the profile](https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/328812c879b56104b7c2bf580d79650a7c20f05b/lib/assets/profile.js#L153), which [should be `true` by default for HTML](https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/328812c879b56104b7c2bf580d79650a7c20f05b/lib/assets/profile.js#L187), and [`false` by default for other profiles](https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/328812c879b56104b7c2bf580d79650a7c20f05b/lib/assets/profile.js#L54). I can't seem to find a way to make this work in VS Code, it will always use the attribute name as the value. I've tried in both HTML and JSX. Steps to Reproduce: 1. In an HTML file or similar type `div[contenteditable]` or `div[whatever.]` and expand with Emmet 2. Observe that the output is `
` or `
` 3. Set `emmet.syntaxProfiles` to: ```json { "html": { "compact_bool": true } } ``` 4. Try again, no luck. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: New emmet doesn't work in sass files
data.body:
Emmet works as expected in css,less,scss files, but not sass files.

Root cause: 

https://github.com/emmetio/css-parser is used to parse the file.
For sass files, this doesn't work and the current node turns out to be null which gets invalidated at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/release/1.15/extensions/emmet/src/abbreviationActions.ts#L161

data.title: CSS Emmet with percentage as unit doesn't show up in suggestion list
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. setting.json 
2. emmet.preferences css.unitAliases

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

The lastest version had removed emmet preference. emmet used to support setting `css.unitAliases` to custom unit variables like set the defualt `rem` to less recaculate variable `@rem`. For example: 
```
 "emmet.preferences": {
    "css.unitAliases": "p:%, r: / @rem"
  },
```

Then i type `w100p` and `tab` could expand to `width: 100%`;

How to accomplish this feature now?

data.title: osx - git crash and create some unknown git track on failed checkout
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6
- Git Version: 2.12.2

I am using vscode intergrated terminal to run git instructions.
Steps to Reproduce: It happens occasionally.
Here is all I did
1. `git add .` The terminal hang for a long time and I closed it.
2.  reopen terminal, try to `git add .` again but throw some error "git .... index.lock". 
3. I manually remove index.lock file and `git add .` again. It works.
4. Now I was in feature-branch. run `git commit .`. 
5. I would like to change to master branch. run `git checkout master`. The terminal hang again.
6. I restart vscode IDE 
7. The git tree is not I expected. Here is the picture
![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/06dBO28.jpg)  

The refund-page is my feature branch. The files I commit on refund-page is preserved.
However, the git tree checkout to an unknown branch. 
The data of unknown branch is the same as master so my files on refund-page is disappeared.

Currently my solution is to rebase and checkout again.
But this happen twice in a day!

My current git tree is really small, around 10 branch and 15 commits.

I am not pretty sure this issue is about git / zsh or vscode ?
I hope I am not report to the wrong place.

Thanks

data.title: Should trees be focused on tab?
data.body:
Steps to reproduce (In stable):
1. `cmd + p` quick pick
2. Focus first item (down arrow)
3. Press `tab` . The whole tree is selected. Another tab to get to the actionbar item.

I feel like it should only be one tab to get to the action item once an entry is focused. Is there any reason why the whole tree is focusable in quick pick? I checked narrator and nvda and they don't seem to read out the tree.

We changed it to not be focusable here: 
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/base/parts/tree/browser/treeView.ts#L448

Is there a reason why the index needs to be 0?

data.title: Fix tabbing in quick pick
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31835 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/31836

- makes the tree view untabbable in order to get to the actionbar item in one tab
- adds a listener for arrow keys and page up/down to focus next/previous entries from a tabbed actionbar state

data.title: No option to automatically terminate previous task when a new instance of the same task is started

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:  1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Creators Update

This is just a suggestion. 

Almost all IDEs allow us to set a 'Single Instance Only' option, When this option is true, And you try to run a task that is already running, It'll kill the running task and then restart it.

VS Code gives an error stating that the task is already running, go to F1->Terminate Task to terminate the task.
This gets really annoying on some machines where to access Function keys, You also need to hold down a separate  "Fn" key. 

My suggestion is to let people specify a `SingleInstanceOnly` option in `tasks.json`, If this option is true, then instead of giving an error to user, It should kill the existing task and restart it. 
And if this option is false, Then just do what it does currently.
Default value should be `false`, So, Only the people who really need this option can set it and others will see the usual behavior 

And, I'd like to work on this, if that's okay. 

Regards 
Ishan

Run process `node --inspect=60005 /server.js --port=123456` 2. Try to attach to it using debugger with launch.config: 
...
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "Attach to Process with fixed Process ID",
            "protocol": "inspector",
            "port": 60005,
            "processId": ""
        } 
...
3. I get the following error: 
messageService.ts:125 Ensure Node was launched with --inspect. Cannot connect to runtime process, timeout after 10000 ms - (reason: Cannot connect to the target: connect ECONNREFUSED 127.0.0.1:9229).
The error should at least have the right port in it. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Returning fontSize to default isn't reflected in open integrated terminals in some cases
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (6feff11ed03402cf77e04e74e13c55529fdb4d09, 2017-08-04T17:53:03.136Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 6.1.7601
- Extensions: none
---

When `terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking` is `false`, an (open) integrated terminal won't update to reflect fontSize changes, when the font size is changed back to default (by either manually assigning the default value, or by removing the line from the User Settings file).

(There may be other settings that force the immediate update, but in testing, I only found/used `terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking`.)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open integrated terminal (tested with bash and cmd)
2. open settings (ctrl + ,)
3. ensure `terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking` is set to `false`
4. set custom `terminal.integrated.fontSize` to a non default value (10, 16, 28, ...)
5. save settings
 (the integrated font size will update to reflect the change)
6. set custom `terminal.integrated.fontSize` to the default value (14) _-or-_ remove the line from the settings
  (the integrated font size will _not_ update to reflect the change)
7. modify some other setting and save _-or-_ close and re-open the integrated terminal
 (the integrated font size will update to reflect the change to `terminal.integrated.fontSize`)

data.title: Mapping emmet mode to a different emmet mode results in double emmet suggestions
data.body:
Use this setting
```
"emmet.includeLanguages": {
	"javascriptreact": "css"
}
```

Below can be see in a jsx file 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16890566/29192379-16152bee-7dd6-11e7-8750-c7fc4a07a0c8.png)
